17.title: Submit A Letter
17.text:
Make sure to include your full name, phone number and address. Only your name will appear in the newspaper or on our website.
Also, please keep your letter under 150 words.
Click here to send your letter to the Editor.

25.title: About
25.text:
About Trades Alberta

Trades Alberta is a series in the Edmonton Journal and the Calgary Herald about industry news and trends on the trades in our province. The editorial project highlights the economic impact of trades professions and effects of anticipated trades shortages on the economy. Look for stories about the youth, programs, people and organizations that are part of this industry

It is produced in partnership with Careers: the Next Generation and with the support of industry partners. Partners are not given the opportunity to put restrictions on the content or review it prior to publication.

Get more information about this project.

Resources

Links, resources and information for students, employees and employers about trades in Alberta.

View full list of resources.

28.title: Who we are: The Calgary Herald Editorial Board
28.text: Who we are: Meet the Calgary Herald Editorial Board

32.title: About Taste Alberta
32.text: Taste Alberta is an editorial series in the Edmonton Journal and the Calgary Herald about the huge variety of food produced and processed in the province, where to buy it, and how to prepare and serve it. It is produced in partnership with ALMA, the Alberta Livestock and Meat Agency, and with the support of Save-On-Foods. Partners are not given the opportunity to put restrictions on the content or to review it prior to publication. Each month, Taste Alberta appears in the Wednesday Food section of the Journal newspaper and in the You section of the Herald newspaper, as well as online. Follow @TasteAlberta for a feed of tasty local stories. To comment or suggest ideas for the series, please contact editor Janet Vlieg at jvlieg@edmontonjournal.com

61.title: What's happening at the Stampede
61.text: See the latest Herald coverage from the Calgary Stampede grounds.

66.text:

Find out what riding you're in
Online voter registration
What ID you need to vote

List of registered political parties

67.title: Inside the series
67.text: For the past year, 2014-15 Michelle Lang Fellowship recipient Dylan Robertson has investigated why some Canadians are drawn to terror groups and what communities are doing to stop homegrown terrorism. Read more about the series and what it covers.

74.title: Local Riding Map
74.text: Find out who won in your riding

75.title: About the Lang Fellowship
75.text: The fellowship is named after The Calgary Herald's Michelle Lang, who died in December 2009 while on assignment in Kandahar, Afghanistan. Read more about Michelle and the fellowship here.

76.title: About the Fund
76.text: The Calgary Herald Christmas Fund was created in 1991 by Herald employees to provide readers with the opportunity to respond to the needs of the city’s social agencies. It has raised more than $22.9 million for local charities since 1991. Read more about the fund.

80.title: The Recipients
80.text: The 2015 Christmas Fund is supporting 14 very worthwhile agencies. Learn more about each organization.

81.title: The Donors: $1,242,841.44 raised
81.text: Thanks to everyone who has generously donated. Tax receipts will be issued no later than Feb. 28, 2016.

82.title: To apply for 2016
82.text: To apply to be a recipient for the 2016 Calgary Herald Christmas Fund, click here The deadline to submit a proposal for the 2016 campaign is June 1, 2016

83.title: Resource Centre
83.text:
Energy sector game changers

Watch now: developments, risks, and trends analysis from experts on the global energy outlook.

 

What Alberta's Climate Leadership Policy means for the energy sector

Experts break down the potential impacts of Alberta’s sweeping new approach to greenhouse gas policy.

 

The Canadian Retail Report: Winter 2016

Practical content to keep you current on the developments that affect retailers in Canada.

 

Global regulatory trends to watch in 2016

As government priorities change, and business models and technology evolve, businesses need to look ahead to the regulatory landscape that will govern their conduct over the next year. In this report, experts weigh in on regulatory trends to watch in 2016.

 

Trans-Pacific Partnership: what you need to know

Experts provide an insightful overview of one of the largest and most ambitious free trade initiatives in history.

 

US Policy Scan for 2016

Outlook and analysis you can use for the year ahead, as the US enters the 2016 presidential election year.

 

Provided by

84.title: Share your story with The People Project

93.title: About this series
93.text: Calgary photojournalist Christina Ryan has waged a near daily battle to bring down the barriers — both figurative and literal — to a richer life for her special-needs daughter, Emily. In this special series, Postmedia shares Ryan's personal story of raising a child with special needs and highlights programs working to expand opportunities for children with disabilities.

96.title: Making Calgary better for children with special needs
96.text: We asked parents, politicians, academics, and a range of community members one simple question: How can we make a better Calgary for children with special needs? Read what they had to say.

97.title: The Immigration Question: How new Canadians will shape the country
97.text: Michelle Lang Fellowship recipient Alia Dharssi is conducting a year-long investigation into the ways immigration, temporary foreign workers and new Canadians will influence the future of Canada. Have an idea or story to share? Send her an email

98.title: About the Lang Fellowship
98.text: The fellowship is named after The Calgary Herald's Michelle Lang, who died in December 2009 while on assignment in Kandahar, Afghanistan. Read more about Michelle and the fellowship here.

4.title: The latest coverage of the rodeo and chuckwagon races
The latest from the Stampede grounds

5.title: Stampede Lookback
5.alt_text: The 1912 Stampede Parade. Click on the image for details.
5.caption: Spectators for the 1912 Stampede Parade were "lined up seven and eight deep on both sides of the streets along the route, and every roof, window, rafter and elevated position of any kind sufficient to bear the weight of a man had its quota of eager faces."

6.title: Stampede Lookback
6.caption: This 1930's photo shows Shriners leading a parade float pulled by heavy horses in the Stampede parade.

74.adv_info_box: This story was produced by the Calgary Herald's Special Projects department on behalf of SAIT Polytechnic for commercial purposes. The Herald's editorial department had no involvement in the creation of this content.

6.description: A notable event we'll probably cover. Once it's assigned, switch Status to Assigned

7.name: Ready to edit
7.description: It's ready for copy editing. Ask for revisions, or Publish/Update
